item.title: Manifolds and Tensors
item.description:
Manifolds

Definition

A manifold is a topological space that locally resembles Euclidean space near each point. More formally, an n-dimensional manifold is a space where every point has a neighborhood that is homeomorphic to an open subset of R‚Åø. This means that for any point on the manifold, you can find a small region around it that behaves like n-dimensional Euclidean space.

Examples

  1. Circle (S¬π): The circle is a 1-dimensional manifold because each point on the circle has a neighborhood that looks like an open interval in R¬π.
  2. Sphere (S¬≤): The sphere is a 2-dimensional manifold because each point on the sphere has a neighborhood that looks like an open disk in R¬≤.
  3. Torus (T¬≤): The torus is a 2-dimensional manifold because each point on the torus has a neighborhood that looks like an open disk in R¬≤.

Charts and Atlases

To work with manifolds, we use charts and atlases. A chart is a homeomorphism from an open subset of the manifold to an open subset of R‚Åø. An atlas is a collection of charts that cover the entire manifold. The transition maps between overlapping charts must be smooth (infinitely differentiable) for the manifold to be considered a smooth manifold.

item.title: Topological Spaces
item.description:
In general relativity, spacetime has the same structure as a topological space. A topological space is a set $X$ equipped with a collection of open subsets $T$ that satisfy the following properties for $O\in T$:

  1. The union of any collection of sets in $T$ is also in $T$: $\text{If } O_\alpha \in T \text{ for all } \alpha \in A, \text{ then } \bigcup_{\alpha \in A} O_\alpha \in T$, then:$$\bigcup_{\alpha \in A} O_\alpha \in T$$
  2. The intersection of any finite number of sets in $T$ is also in $T$: $\text{If } O_1, O_2, \ldots, O_n \in T, \text{ then } U_1 \cap U_2 \cap \ldots \cap U_n \in T$, then:$$\bigcap_{i=1}^{n} O_i \in T$$
  3. The empty set $\emptyset$ and the entire set $X$ are in $T$.
